summary: In Ribeiro v Ribeiro, the Ghanaian Supreme Court, by a 3-2 majority, upheld the lower courts' decision to rescind the husband's transfer of 'Haulage House' to his new wife and order its conveyance to the former wife as part of financial provision under section 20(1) and 26(1) of the Matrimonial Causes Act, 1971 (Act 367). The husband had transferred multiple properties during proceedings, which the courts found to be in bad faith to defeat the wife's claim. The majority affirmed that a spouse's domestic contributions justify financial provision, including property transfer, even without direct financial contribution. The trial court also awarded 150,000 lump sum. The dissenting justices argued that courts lack statutory authority to transfer titled property absent proprietary interest and that financial provision should be limited to monetary awards. The case exposed deep judicial division on the scope of judicial discretion in marital property distribution.
verdict: Appeal dismissed by Supreme Court (3-2 majority); affirmed High Court and Court of Appeal decisions to rescind property transfer and award financial provision.
rationaleHighlights: Court may rescind asset dispositions made to defeat financial claims under s.26(1)
Domestic services entitle spouse to financial provision despite no financial contribution
Discretion to award financial provision includes property conveyance if intended to defeat claims
Dissent argues courts lack power to transfer property without proprietary interest
Transfer during proceedings with continued control indicates bad faith
Affluent spouse should provide adequate accommodation regardless of title
